Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the progress made in constructing tarmac roads in the last five years by stating that 7,000 kilometers were constructed, compared to 12,000 kilometers in the previous 50 years.
Understate: The claim may be understating the progress made in connecting people to electricity in the last five years by stating that 6.9 million people were connected, compared to only 2.3 million in the previous 50 years.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that a standard-gauge railway of 600 kilometers was built in the last five years, as mentioned by the expert.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or evidence to back up the numbers provided for tarmac construction and electricity connections.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the progress made in the last five years is significantly better than the progress made in the previous 50 years without providing sufficient context or evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or factors contributing to the differences in numbers mentioned in the claim, such as changes in government policies, funding availability, or technological advancements.
